questions.text: What is the dose range of lithium in mEq/dL for acute attacks of mania and long-term maintenance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.6 to 1.5 mEq/dL

 

Lithium has a narrow therapeutic window and its serum concentrations need careful monitoring.

 

0.6 to 1.5 mEq/dL represents the general therapeutic range for lithium. According to 12th edition of Synopsis of Psychiatry,  for acute manic episodes, the target serum lithium level is between 1.0 to 1.2 mEq/dL, while for long-term maintenance, it is 0.4 to 0.8 mEq/dL. The option closes to this range is option C.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.5 to 1 mEq/dL is close but not the typical therapeutic range. It is on the lower end and might not be effective for many patients, especially during acute mania.

 

Option B. 0.1 to 0.5 mEq/dL is subtherapeutic. Such low levels wouldn't be effective for the treatment of bipolar disorder and would not offer the necessary mood-stabilizing effects.

 

Option D. 2 to 3 mEq/dL is a toxic range. Lithium concentrations at this level can result in severe side effects and even life-threatening toxicity.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 655

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of fever, rash, body ache, and throat ache. He has a history of thorn prick injury a week back. What antibiotics would you give empirically to this child? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amoxicilin +clavulanate

 

The symptoms described in this case—fever, rash, sore throat, and body aches—following a thorn prick injury suggest the possibility of scarlet fever caused by Group A Streptococcus (GAS). Scarlet fever typically presents with a diffuse erythematous rash, which may be papular, along with other symptoms such as a sore throat, body aches, and the characteristic "strawberry tongue."

 

Key Points:

 

  • Scarlet Fever and GAS: Scarlet fever is most commonly caused by GAS and is characterized by the production of pyrogenic (erythrogenic) exotoxin, leading to the rash and other systemic symptoms.
  • Empirical Antibiotic Treatment:
    • Amoxicillin + Clavulanate: This combination is a first-line treatment for infections caused by GAS, particularly when there is a concern for beta-lactamase-producing bacteria. Clavulanate inhibits beta-lactamase enzymes, allowing amoxicillin to remain effective against the bacteria.
    • Penicillin or Amoxicillin alone is generally the treatment of choice for scarlet fever, but adding clavulanate broadens the spectrum to cover potential mixed infections.
  • Diagnostic Confirmation: While empirical treatment is initiated, a rapid antigen detection test or throat culture for Streptococcus should be performed to confirm the diagnosis of GAS infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that is typically reserved for more severe infections requiring hospitalization. It is not the first choice for uncomplicated scarlet fever.

 

Option C. Vancomycin. and Option D. Meropenem: These are higher-tier antibiotics reserved for severe or resistant infections, often guided by culture and sensitivity results. They are not typically used as first-line treatment in cases of suspected scarlet fever or mild GAS infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a child presenting with symptoms suggestive of scarlet fever following a thorn prick injury, empirical antibiotic treatment with amoxicillin + clavulanate is appropriate while awaiting diagnostic confirmation of Group A Streptococcus infection.

questions.text: Which virus can be identified by a PCR method and is endemic to India? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) West Nile Virus

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) can cause neurological disease and death in people. WNV is commonly found in Africa, Europe, the Middle East, North America and West Asia. In Mumbai in the year 1952, the antibodies against WNV were first detected in humans. Since then, the virus activity has been reported in southern, central, and western India. WNV is maintained in nature in a cycle involving transmission between birds and mosquitoes. Humans, horses and other mammals can be infected.

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) is a member of the flavivirus genus and belongs to the Japanese encephalitis antigenic complex of the family Flaviviridae.

 

West Nile virus can be diagnosed by a number of different tests:

 

  • IgG antibody sero-conversion (or significant increase in antibody titers) in two serial specimen collected at a one week interval by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA);
  • IgM antibody capture enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA);
  • neutralisation assays;
  • viral detection by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay, and
  • virus isolation by cell culture.

 

IgM can be detected in nearly all cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and serum specimens received from WNV infected patients at the time of their clinical presentation. Serum IgM antibody may persist for more than a year.

 

Other options:

 

Option A: Hendra virus is endemic to Australia

 

Option C: Ebola virus is endemic to Africa.

 

Option D: Yellow fever endemic to South and Central America, and certain parts of Africa.

 

Educational Objective

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) can be identified by PCR and is endemic to India, with significant historical and ongoing presence, making it a critical pathogen for regional public health monitoring and response.

choices.text: A, B, C, D
A, C, D

questions.text:
Which of the following can be used to calculate the cardiac output? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. ECHO.
  2. Ventilation-perfusion scan.
  3. Thermodilution.
  4. Fick's principle
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A, C, D

 

Fick principle, thermodilution, and ECHO can be used to measure cardiac output.

 

Cardiac output is the amount of blood pumped by the heart into the aorta every minute. The average cardiac output is 5L/min and can be measured by various indirect methods.

 

Option A. Doppler echocardiography is a method for detecting the direction and velocity of moving blood within the heart. This is also a popular method to measure cardiac output.

 

Option C. Thermodilution method - a known volume of cold sterile solution is injected into the right atrium via inferior vena cava by using a catheter. Cardiac output is measured by determining the resultant change in the blood temperature in pulmonary artery. For this purpose, two thermistors (temperature transducers) are used. One of them is placed in the inferior vena cava and the second one is placed in pulmonary artery. A pulmonary artery catheter is used to place the thermistors in their positions.

 

Option D. The Fick principle, as applied to cardiac output, relies on the recognition that the total uptake of oxygen by the peripheral tissues is equal to the product of the blood flow to the peripheral tissues and the arterial-venous oxygen concentration difference.

Formula:

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Indirect methods used to measure cardiac output:

 

  1. By using Fick principle
  2. Indicator (dye) dilution technique
  3. Thermodilution technique
  4. Ultrasonic Doppler transducer technique
  5. Doppler echocardiography
  6. Ballisto cardiography.

choices.text: Echocardiography for cardiac disease
Urine analysis for bacteriuria
Blood sugar levels for GDM
VDRL for syphilis

questions.text: The following cost-effective investigations are routinely recommended in the screening of antenatal mothers except? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echocardiography for cardiac disease

 

Explanation:

 

Echocardiography for cardiac disease is not part of routine antenatal screening. While it is important for detecting cardiac conditions, echocardiography is typically performed only if there is a known or suspected cardiac disease. Routine screening for all antenatal mothers does not include echocardiography due to its cost and the specific indications required for its use.

 

Routine antenatal screening is designed to identify common conditions that may affect the health of the mother and baby.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Urine analysis for bacteriuriaUrine analysis for bacteriuria: This test is routinely performed to detect asymptomatic bacteriuria, which, if left untreated, can lead to urinary tract infections and increase the risk of preterm labor.

 

Option C. Blood sugar levels for GDM Blood sugar levels for GDM (Gestational Diabetes Mellitus): Screening for GDM is essential to identify women who develop diabetes during pregnancy, which can affect both maternal and fetal health.

 

Option D. VDRL for syphilis: The VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) test is a screening tool for syphilis, a sexually transmitted infection that can have serious consequences for both the mother and the baby if left untreated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Routine antenatal screening does not include echocardiography for cardiac disease unless there is a known or suspected condition.

 

Ref: Page no 110, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text:
What is the sequence of heart sounds heard from the top to the bottom of the left side of the chest wall? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Pulmonary
  2. Aortic
  3. Mitral
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 ➔ 2 ➔ 3
 

The sequence of cardiac sounds as they're perceived on the left side of the chest, from top to bottom, is outlined below:

 

  1. Pulmonary - detected in the second intercostal space.
  2. Aortic - can be heard at the neoaortic region or Erb's point, situated in the second intercostal space.
  3. Mitral - observed at the fifth intercostal space.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of heart sounds heard from the top to the bottom of the left side of the chest wall is: Pulmonary (second intercostal space), Aortic (second intercostal space), and Mitral (fifth intercostal space).

questions.text: A 21-year-old female was brought dead to the casualty. On examination there was frothing from her nose and mouth. What is the likely cause of death? (INICET NOVEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Drowning

 

The image shows frothing from nostrils which is likely to be due to drowning.

 

Postmortem changes of drowning:

 

  • Bloody froth in the airway

  • Water in the stomach and small intestine

  • Water in middle ear

  • Cerebral edema

  • Bloated and cyanosed face

  • Petrous or mastoid hemorrhage.

  • Voluminous / ballooned out lungs

  • Suffused conjunctive, dilated pupils

  • "Washerwoman" changes of the hands (shriveling of the skin) develop when submerged in water for several hours

  • Cutis anserina / goose skin- The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin.

  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning.

  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.

  • Diatom test

 

Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hanging: Typically presents with a ligature mark around the neck, not frothing.

 

Option C. Strangulation: Often shows signs of external trauma to the neck, such as bruising or fractures, but not frothing.

 

Option D. Traumatic asphyxia: This results from severe chest compression, leading to petechiae and cyanosis but not usually frothing from the nose and mouth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frothing from the nose and mouth, along with other specific postmortem findings, strongly suggests drowning as the cause of death.

questions.text:
What is the antidote of cyanide poisoning? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

A. Amyl Nitrite
B. Sodium Nitrite
C. Sodium Thiosulphate
D. Benzyl Thiocyanate
E. Sodium Nitroprusside
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ABC

 

Cyanide poisoning inhibits cytochrome C oxidase, a key enzyme in the mitochondrial electron transport chain, leading to cellular hypoxia and lactic acidosis. The treatment for cyanide poisoning involves agents that either bind to cyanide, facilitating its excretion, or convert it into a less toxic form.

 

A. Amyl Nitrite and B. Sodium Nitrite: These compounds oxidize hemoglobin to methemoglobin, which has a higher affinity for cyanide than cytochrome C oxidase. This process frees cytochrome C oxidase and forms cyanmethemoglobin.

 

C. Sodium Thiosulphate: This compound acts directly by converting cyanmethemoglobin to thiocyanate, which is less toxic and is excreted in the urine. Additionally, it directly breaks the bond between cytochrome C oxidase and cyanide.

 

D. Benzyl Thiocyanate: This is not a recognized treatment for cyanide poisoning and does not have the properties needed to detoxify cyanide.

 

E. Sodium Nitroprusside: This compound, while containing cyanide groups, is not used as an antidote for cyanide poisoning. It is actually a source of cyanide and is used for different medical purposes, such as vasodilation in hypertensive emergencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The main antidotes for cyanide poisoning include amyl nitrite, sodium nitrite, and sodium thiosulphate. These agents work by either converting cyanide into a less toxic form or by forming methemoglobin which binds to cyanide, freeing cytochrome C oxidase.
