  2. Cytokine mediated integrin activation
  3. Adhesion
  4. Migration
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Correct sequence of events during inflammation:

 

  1. Rolling
  2. Cytokine mediated integrin activation
  3. Adhesion
  4. Migration

 

CELLULAR CHANGES DURING INFLAMMATION

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of intravascular cellular events during inflammation involves rolling, cytokine-mediated integrin activation, adhesion, and migration.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition pg. 78-79

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with complaints of nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip. There is a past history of FESS (Functional endoscopic sinus surgery) for failed conservative management 5 years ago. Uncinectomy and maxillary ostium dilation was done during the previous FESS. A DNE done now shows patent ostia and mucosal edema of the maxillary sinus lining. What is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Steroid irrigation and antihistamines

 

The next best step in management in this patient is steroid irrigation and antihistamines.

 

This patient who had previously undergone FESS 5 years ago for failed medical management now has nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip suggestive of acute rhinosinusitis.

 

Acute rhinosinusitis usually develops along with viral upper respiratory tract infection due to mucosal swelling causing obstruction of the sinus ostia. Persistent or worsening symptoms even after 10 days with fever and purulent discharge indicates secondary bacterial infection.

 

Treatment initially is symptomatic with -

 

  • First line of treatment - Nasal steroid irrigation, decongestants, and antihistamines
  • In cases of secondary bacterial infection antibiotics are indicated. Amoxyclav is the drug of choice.
  • Biological therapy is not used in the treatment of sinusitis. It may be used in cases of refractory polyp.
  • Revision surgery is indicated only when maximal medical therapy has failed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat Surgery: Indicated only if there are anatomical obstructions or complications that cannot be managed medically. In this case, the DNE shows patent ostia, so repeat surgery is not indicated without further evidence of structural issues.

 

Option B. Macrolides for 4 months: Could be considered for their anti-inflammatory properties in some chronic rhinosinusitis cases, but there is no mention of bacterial infection needing long-term antibiotics, making this less suitable than symptomatic management.

 

Option D. Biological Therapy: Mainly used for refractory cases with specific underlying conditions such as severe asthma or nasal polyps, which is not indicated here based on the provided scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip post-FESS with no current acute infection or structural issues, conservative management using steroid irrigation and antihistamines is recommended to manage inflammation and alleviate symptoms.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 213, 214

questions.text: Decreased sexual maturity and hypogonadism seen with deficiency of: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc

 

Zinc is an essential trace element involved in numerous aspects of cellular metabolism. It plays a vital role in immune function, protein synthesis, wound healing, DNA synthesis, and cell division. Zinc is also crucial for normal growth and development during pregnancy, childhood, and adolescence, and it is necessary for the proper functioning of taste and smell.

 

Features of Zinc Deficiency:

 

  • Decreased Sexual Maturity: Zinc deficiency in children and adolescents can lead to growth retardation and delayed sexual maturation, particularly hypogonadism in males.
  • Hypogonadism: This condition is characterized by the underdevelopment of primary or secondary sexual characteristics, such as the testes in males, leading to delayed or absent puberty.
  • Impaired Immune Function: Zinc deficiency can result in an increased susceptibility to infections.
  • Other Symptoms: Include hair loss, diarrhea, delayed wound healing, and eye and skin lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper: Deficiency can lead to anemia (microcytic, hypochromic), neutropenia, bone abnormalities, and neurological issues such as peripheral neuropathy and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord.

 

Option C. Selenium: Deficiency can cause Keshan disease (a type of cardiomyopathy) and Kashin-Beck disease (a type of osteoarthropathy).

 

Option D. Iron: Deficiency is commonly associated with microcytic, hypochromic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency is associated with decreased sexual maturity and hypogonadism, particularly in male children, and is a common nutritional deficiency in developing countries. It is also linked to impaired growth, immune dysfunction, and delayed wound healing.

questions.text: A boy presents with fever, night sweats, and neck swelling. The biopsy of swelling showed a starry sky appearance. What is the most likely genetic abnormality seen in this case? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MYC gene

 

The given clinical scenario and the classical histopathological finding of starry sky appearance suggest the diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma and the most likely genetic abnormality is the translocation of the MYC gene on chromosome 8. Typical cytogenetic abnormalities is t(8;14) and t(8;22) involving MYC gene on chromosome 8, with overexpression of MYC protein having transforming activity.

 

Burkitt lymphoma is very aggressive (very high Ki67) but responds well to intensive chemotherapy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RAS: Mutations in the RAS gene are associated with various cancers, including some leukemias and solid tumors, but not specifically with Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Option C. BCR-ABL: This genetic abnormality is associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and some cases of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), not with Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Option D. p53: Mutations in the p53 gene are common in many types of cancer but are not the defining feature of Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkitt's lymphoma is characterized by the t(8;14) translocation involving the MYC gene, which leads to the overexpression of the MYC protein, driving the aggressive nature of the disease. The starry sky appearance on histopathology is a key diagnostic feature.

 

Ref: Robbins Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1123

questions.text: Imagine a scenario where a novel medication is introduced that significantly reduces mortality from a specific disease but does not actually cure the disease. As patients continue to live longer with the disease due to this medication, it would have an effect on the epidemiological metrics. Which of the following statements correctly describes the expected change in prevalence and incidence as a result of this medication? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase in prevalence

 

  • The given scenario shows that there is a drug which can reduce mortality but cannot cure a particular disease.
  • So, old cases will live longer and thus, there will be increase in prevalence. Incidence will not get affected due to this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in incidence: Incorrect, as the medication does not affect the rate at which new cases occur.

 

Option B. Decrease in prevalence: Incorrect, since patients living longer with the disease will increase prevalence.

 

Option C. Increase in incidence: Incorrect, because incidence measures new cases, not the duration or survival of existing cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PREVALENCE

 

  • Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d]
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery

 

INCIDENCE

 

  • Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

questions.text:
Which of the following are a part of the limbic system?(INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Amygdala

2. Hippocampus

3. Thalamus
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1, 2, 3

 

Explanation:

 

The limbic system is a complex set of brain structures located on both sides of the thalamus, immediately beneath the cerebrum. It includes key components such as the amygdala, hippocampus, thalamus, hypothalamus, basal ganglia, and cingulate gyrus. These structures support a variety of functions related to emotions, behavior, motivation, long-term memory, and olfaction.

 

  1. Amygdala: Integral for processing emotions, the amygdala is especially involved in fear, anxiety, and social cognition. It also plays a significant role in forming and retrieving emotional memories.
  2. Hippocampus: Essential for learning and memory, the hippocampus is pivotal in the consolidation of information from short-term memory to long-term memory and spatial navigation.
  3. Thalamus: Although primarily known as the relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex, the thalamus also supports functions of the limbic system by regulating consciousness, sleep, and alertness.

 

Other structures are :

 

The hypothalamus is involved in regulating many bodily functions, including hunger, thirst, body temperature, and circadian rhythms. It also plays a key role in the regulation of the autonomic nervous system and the endocrine system.

 

The cingulate gyrus is involved in a variety of functions, including emotion regulation, attention, and the processing of pain.

 

Together, these structures form a complex network that plays a crucial role in many aspects of human behavior and cognition. Dysfunction or damage to the limbic system can lead to a range of neurological and psychiatric disorders, including Alzheimer's disease, depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The limbic system’s role is critical, as its structures are deeply integrated into the processes governing emotions, memory, and essential physiological functions. Damage or dysfunction in any part of the limbic system can lead to profound psychological and cognitive impairments, affecting everything from emotional regulation to memory processing.

questions.text: For which medical condition is the provided drug typically recommended? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Malaria

 

The picture depicts artemisin-based combination therapy (ACT). This medicine is used to treat falciparum malaria.

 

ARTEMISINS - Artesunate and Artemether

 

  • Fastest acting anti-malarial
  • Effective against MDR parasites
  • Short acting
  • C/I in 1st trimester

 

Artemisin Combination Therapy [ACT]

 

  • Artemisin + Long acting drug
  • DOC for chloroquine resistant malaria Combinations
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North Eastern States
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine: DOC for rest of India
  • The dose of artesunate is 200 mg OD for 3 days whereas sulfadoxine (1500 mg) and pyrimethamine (75 mg) should be taken on day 1 only

 

Educational Objective:

 

Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT), is typically recommended for the treatment of falciparum malaria.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient weighing 60 kg is on mechanical ventilation for ARDS secondary to urosepsis. The respiratory parameters are as follows: tidal volume- 360 mL; frequency- 30 breaths/min; PEEP- 5 cm of H2O; and FiO2- 90%. The arterial blood gas findings are as follows: paO2- 50 mmHg; paCO2- 38 mmHg and pH- 7.38. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase PEEP

 

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) requires careful management of mechanical ventilation settings to optimize oxygenation while minimizing lung injury. The patient's current settings and blood gas findings suggest hypoxemia (paO2 of 50 mmHg) with an FiO2 of 90%. The goal in managing ARDS is to maintain adequate oxygenation (paO2 > 60 mmHg) while reducing the FiO2 to less than 60% to avoid oxygen toxicity.

 

Increasing PEEP is the best option to improve oxygenation. PEEP helps to keep alveoli open, improving gas exchange and oxygenation. By increasing PEEP, we can potentially increase the paO2 and eventually reduce the FiO2 to safer levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduce FiO2: Although reducing FiO2 is a long-term goal to prevent oxygen toxicity, it is not advisable to reduce it immediately because the patient is currently hypoxemic (paO2 of 50 mmHg).

 

Option B. Increase tidal volume: Not appropriate as it can increase the risk of ventilator-induced lung injury in ARDS patients. The current tidal volume is within the safe range (360 mL), which is appropriate for a 60 kg patient as it falls within the recommended range of 4-6 mL/kg for ARDS patients to prevent ventilator-induced lung injury.

 

Option C. Increase respiratory rate: Increasing the respiratory rate is not necessary in this situation as the paCO2 (38 mmHg) and pH (7.38) indicate normal ventilation and no significant respiratory acidosis (paCO2 is normal).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ARDS management, if the patient remains hypoxemic despite a high FiO2, the next step is to increase the PEEP to improve oxygenation while maintaining lung-protective ventilation strategies.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of NAME syndrome? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ebstein's anomaly

 

NAME syndrome stands for Nevus, Atrial myxoma, Myxoid neurofibroma, and Ephelides (freckles) or Endocrine overactivity (such as pheochromocytoma). 

 

Ebstein's anomaly, which is a congenital heart defect characterized by the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve, is not a component of NAME syndrome. 

 

Ebstein's anomaly is associated with maternal lithium use during pregnancy rather than being a component of NAME syndrome. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Components of NAME Syndrome

 

 

Ebstein's anomaly is not part of this syndrome but is associated with maternal lithium exposure during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child has taken 10 iron tablets and presents with nausea and abdominal pain. What should be given to the child? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Desferrioxamine.

 

  • Desferrioxamine is an antidote of iron toxicity. It is an intravenous iron-chelating compound. It can be safely administered in children. It is drug of choice for acute iron poisoning.

  • Deferipirone is oral iron chelator and is drug of choice for chronic iron poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Penicillamine: It is a copper chelating agent. It is used in Wilson’s disease.

 

Option C. Dimercaprol or British Anti Lewisite or BAL: Is used in heavy metal poisonings like mercury, arsenic, lead.

 

Option D. EDTA: Is a chelating agent which is used as an antidote for lead poisoning.

 

Educational Objective :

 

In cases of acute iron poisoning, particularly in children, Desferrioxamine is the appropriate treatment. It is an intravenous iron-chelating agent that binds free iron, facilitating its excretion and mitigating the toxic effects of the overdose. Other chelating agents like penicillamine, BAL, and EDTA are used for different types of heavy metal poisonings and are not suitable for treating iron toxicity.

choices.text: Central line insertion
Arterial line insertion

questions.text: The given set of instruments are used in? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Airway management

 

Explanation:

 

The instruments shown in the image are part of an airway cart. The equipment typically found in an airway cart is designed for managing the airway during anesthesia or in emergency situations. The contents of the airway cart usually include:

 

  • Laryngoscope: A device used to obtain a view of the vocal folds and the glottis, which is essential for endotracheal intubation.
  • Tracheal tubes of various sizes: These tubes are used to secure the airway by passing through the trachea.
  • Masks: Various types of masks to deliver oxygen or anesthetic gases.
  • Laryngeal mask airways (LMA): A device placed over the laryngeal inlet to provide ventilation.
  • Flexible fiberoptic intubation equipment: Used for intubation in difficult airway situations.
  • Retrograde intubation equipment: Tools used for intubation when conventional methods fail.
  • Front of neck access equipment: Devices for surgical airway access.
  • Equipment required for emergency invasive airway access: Tools needed for emergency tracheostomy or cricothyrotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central line insertion: This procedure requires different instruments such as central venous catheters, guidewires, dilators, and sterile drapes.

 

Option B. Arterial line insertion: This involves the use of arterial catheters, guidewires, and transducers, not typically found in an airway cart.

 

Option D. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR): CPR primarily requires defibrillators, chest compression devices, and basic airway management tools like bag-valve masks (BVM), but not the comprehensive set shown for airway management.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The instruments in an airway cart are specifically designed for various procedures involved in airway management, including intubation and emergency airway access.

choices.text: Right internal jugular vein
Cervical sympathetic chain
Left vagus nerve
Right internal carotid artery

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl committed suicide by hanging, after a fight with her boyfriend. On conducting the autopsy, the ligature mark is seen at the lower 1/3rd of the neck and she is seen to have a protruded tongue. One side eye is open and both the pupils are dilated. What is the cause for the open eye? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cervical sympathetic chain

 

In hanging, the ligature knot presses the cervical sympathetic Ganglion, this causes eye on the same side to remain open and pupil dilated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right internal jugular vein: Compression would cause venous congestion but is not directly related to the open eye and dilated pupil.

 

Option C. Left vagus nerve: Compression would affect parasympathetic innervation, potentially leading to bradycardia, but not the open eye and dilated pupil.

 

Option D. Right internal carotid artery: Compression could lead to ischemia, but it does not explain the unilateral open eye and pupil dilation.

 

Educational Objective

 

PM findings of hanging in the Neck

 

  • Petechiae-Tardieu spot
  • La facies sympathique
  • Salivary dribbling
  • Ligature mark
  • Tissues under ligature mark are dry, pale, and glistening
  • Thyroid cartilage
  • Hyoid bone fracture

questions.text:
Which of the following statement/s is/are true regarding open fracture?(INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Compartment syndrome is rare.
  2. Immediate debridement should be done.
  3. Tibia is the most common long bone involved.
  4. Multiple fractures are uncommon.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) I, II & III are correct

 

I. Compartment syndrome is rare: True

 

  • In open fractures, the fascia may be disrupted, which reduces the risk of rising compartment pressure.

  • However, compartment syndrome can still occur, especially in high-energy injuries, so it is not impossible, but it is less common compared to closed fractures.

 

II. Immediate debridement should be done: True

 

  • Early and thorough surgical debridement is the cornerstone of open fracture management to reduce infection risk.

  • Ideally performed within 6–8 hours, though recent evidence suggests that a short delay may not significantly change infection rates if antibiotics are given promptly.

 

III. Tibia is the most common long bone involved: True

 

  • The tibia is the most commonly involved long bone in open fractures due to its subcutaneous location (minimal soft tissue coverage).

  • Therefore, it’s more vulnerable to open injuries, especially in road traffic accidents.

 

IV. Multiple fractures are uncommon: False

  • Multiple fractures are actually common, particularly in high-energy trauma like road traffic accidents, falls from height, or blast injuries.

  • Open fractures often occur as part of polytrauma.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In open fracture, compartment syndrome is a rare entity as the fracture communicates with the surrounding atmosphere, preventing an increase in the compartment pressure.
  • These fractures need immediate irrigation with antibiotics and debridement of the wound.
  • Tibia is the most common site for open fractures after phalanges.

questions.text:
Arrange the following external fixators used for treatment of fracture of tibia in order of increasing stability: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Ilizarov

  2. Uniplanar frame with one rod

  3. Biplanar frame

  4. Uniplanar frame with two rods
questions.solution:
Ans. A. II, IV, III, I

 

EXTERNAL FIXATION

 

  • In External fixation, the fixation device is external to skin.

  • Uniplanar frame with one rod provides the least stability as it can only resist forces in one plane.

  • In uniplanar frame with two rods, adding a second rod increases stability compared to a single rod.

  • Biplanar frame provides stability in two planes, making it more secure than uniplanar frames. It improves the resistance to rotational and bending forces.

  • The Ilizarov external fixator is known for its exceptional stability due to its ring structure and multiple pins. It provides high axial and torsional stability.

  • It is often used for complex fractures and lengthening procedures.

  • Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis i.e., an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently lengthening can be done.

  • It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union and also for CTEV.

  • Therefore, the Ilizarov fixator offers the highest level of stability among the options listed.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For the fixation of tibia fracture, the order of external fixators used in order of increased stability is:

 

Uniplanar frame with one rod (II) < uniplanar frame with two rods (IV) < biplanar frame (III) < ilizarov (I)

choices.text: Total lack of natural killer cells
Decrease in lgG and increase in lgM
Inability of neutrophils to fight against infections

questions.text: Which of the subsequent statements accurately describes the immunological anomaly associated with the absence of CD40 in B cells? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in lgG and increase in lgM

 

The absence of CD40 and its deficiency in B cells results in Hyper IgM syndrome. This condition is characterized by a reduction in IgG levels and an elevation in IgM levels.

 

HYPER IGM SYNDROME

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total lack of natural killer cells: This is not associated with CD40 deficiency but rather with other immune disorders like severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

 

Option B. Lack of CD8 mediated cytotoxicity: CD40/CD40L interactions do not directly affect CD8 T cells. CD8 mediated cytotoxicity is more related to T cell receptor function and MHC class I interactions.

 

Option D. Inability of neutrophils to fight against infections: While CD40 deficiency can lead to an increased susceptibility to infections, neutrophil function is not directly impaired by the absence of CD40. This function is more related to chronic granulomatous disease or other neutrophil defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyper IgM syndrome is characterized by an increased level of IgM and decreased levels of other immunoglobulins like IgG, due to a defect in the CD40/CD40L interaction necessary for immunoglobulin class switching.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in sequential order with regards to the steps of collection of samples for pap smear testing: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Use posterior vaginal wall retractor
  2. Take the sample
  3. Make smear on a slide
  4. Fix the smear
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

The correct sequence for the steps of collection of samples for pap smear testing is as follows:

 

Procedure of taking a pap smear:

 

  1. Use posterior vaginal wall retractor: The patient is put in a dorsal position, and Cusco's speculum is introduced to visualize the cervix.
  2. Take the sample: The ectocervix is scraped with Ayre's spatula, and the endocervix is scraped with a cytobrush.
  3. Make smear on a slide: The samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides.
  4. Fix the smear: The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol (either immersed or sprayed). After immersion in fixative for 30 minutes, the slide is removed and air dried.

 

Additional Steps:

 

  • Staining: The fixed slide is stained with Papanicolaou stain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for collecting samples for a pap smear is to first use a posterior vaginal wall retractor to visualize the cervix, take the sample, make the smear on a slide, and then fix the smear using 95% ethyl alcohol.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 632, 633

questions.text: Which extracellular cell adhesion is disrupted by Vibrio cholerae? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Occludens

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio cholerae disrupts occludens, specifically targeting tight junctions between intestinal epithelial cells, which impairs their barrier function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Integrin: Primarily involved in cell-extracellular matrix adhesion, not typically disrupted by Vibrio cholerae.

 

Option B. Cadherin: Important for cell-cell adhesion in adherens junctions, not the main target of Vibrio cholerae.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect, as occludens are indeed affected by Vibrio cholerae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio cholerae specifically targets occludens, which are crucial components of tight junctions, thereby compromising intestinal epithelial barrier functions.

choices.text: Radical/ wide excision of GB fossa

questions.text: A patent underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The histopathology specimen reveals carcinoma with invasion into the muscularis propria. What is the next best step? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Radical/ wide excision of GB fossa

 

  • In the scenario of a patient with a gallbladder carcinoma discovered incidentally following a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, where the carcinoma has invaded the muscularis propria, the next step in management should focus on ensuring complete removal of any residual malignant tissue and preventing local recurrence.
  • Radical or wide excision of the gallbladder fossa is the recommended course of action. This involves excising the gallbladder bed to the level of the liver parenchyma and possibly lymph node dissection to ensure any potential spread or residual disease is addressed. This approach is supported by the need to achieve negative margins, as gallbladder cancer can be aggressive and has a tendency to infiltrate the liver and surrounding structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiotherapy and B. Chemotherapy might be considered as adjunct therapies depending on the stage of the cancer, pathological findings from the re-excision, and the patient's overall health status. However, they are not the primary step immediately following the discovery of invasive gallbladder cancer in a post-cholecystectomy specimen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radical/wide excision of the GB fossa is indeed the appropriate next step to prevent local recurrence and potentially improve survival outcomes. This decision is based on the depth of tumor invasion and the general aggressiveness of gallbladder cancers.

questions.text: In this case, a young boy is exhibiting symptoms of reduced mood, decreased energy, and diminished engagement with his environment. He has refrained from eating for the past week and his thoughts include phrases like "I have lost my mind. I am deceased. How can I consume food?". What is the specific delusion in this scenario? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nihilistic delusion

 

Nihilistic delusion (delusion of negation, Cotard syndrome): Patients may deny the existence of their body, their mind, or the world in general. For example, a patient with severe depression claimed that all his internal organs have rotted.

 

Here, the best answer is Nihilistic delusion rather than Cotard syndrome because the question has specifically asked the type of delusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypochondriacal delusion: Hypochondriacal delusion is an illness anxiety disorder. It is characterized by a preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious physical illness. The preoccupation persists despite normal investigations and medical reassurances.

 

Option D. Bizarre delusion: Scientifically impossible and culturally implausible (un-understandable). For example, a patient claimed that aliens stole his heart and lungs, and now he is living without those organs.

choices.text: Z line, A band, H zone, I Band
A band, Z line, H zone, M Band
A band, I Band, Z line, H zone
Z line, A band, M Band, H zone

questions.text: Identify the correct labeling (A, B, C, D) in the given image? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Z line, A band, H zone, I Band

 

  • A is the Z line: The light line marking the boundary between sarcomeres
  • B (A band): The darker, thicker region representing myosin filaments
  • C (H zone):  The lighter area between the A bands
  • D (I Band): The lighter area between Z lines containing actin filaments

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with confusion, constipation, and persistent low mood. ALP was elevated. She was diagnosed with primary hyperparathyroidism. Which of the following is the imaging of choice? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sestamibi scan

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features of 40-year-old woman with confusion, constipation, along with persistent low mood is suggestive of hypercalcemia, which could be due to primary Hyperparathyroidism.

 

IOC for parathyroid adenoma: Tc99-Sestamibi scan

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI: While MRI can provide detailed soft tissue images, it is not the preferred imaging modality for detecting parathyroid adenomas.

 

Option B. FDG PET: PET scans are used in cancer imaging and are not specific for identifying parathyroid adenomas.

 

Option C. CT: While CT scans can identify anatomical details and some tumors, they lack the specificity of Sestamibi scans in identifying hyperactive parathyroid tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Sestamibi scan is specifically useful for identifying parathyroid adenomas in patients suspected of having primary hyperparathyroidism, due to its ability to effectively localize hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

questions.text: A study involved 30,000 women who were monitored for a period of 10 years to track the occurrence of breast cancer. Among them, 1200 women developed cancer and were subsequently given a questionnaire to evaluate potential risk factors. In parallel, 2000 women from the same study served as controls and were also subjected to the questionnaire. What is the name of this type of study? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Nested case control

 

  • Given scenario dictates that a population was monitored for development of breast cancer.
  • Out of which, 1200 women developed breast cancer and a small subgroup was taken as control.
  • This study structure points to Nested case control study.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: Cohort study involves selecting Exposed and non-exposed groups then follow them for development of outcome.

 

Option B. Retrospective cohort: In Retrospective cohort, the outcomes have already occurred before the study begins.

 

Option D. Cross control cohort: Cross control cohort is not a study design.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A nested case-control study involves identifying cases and controls from an existing cohort that is being followed over time, making it a cost-effective way to study the associations between exposures and outcomes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to your clinic for her postpartum checkup. She mentions that she has been exclusively breastfeeding her newborn and is concerned about meeting her own nutritional needs in order to ensure the best for her baby. She asks you about specific nutrient supplementation she might need during this period of lactation. Compared to her pregnancy, which nutrient would you recommend she should pay particular attention to increasing? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Vitamin A

 

  • The requirement for Vitamin A increases during lactation more than during pregnancy.
  • Vitamin A is essential for ensuring the quality of breast milk, which is the sole source of nutrition for a newborn.
  • It plays a critical role in the development of the baby’s immune system and visual function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to the latest Nutritional Guidelines,

 

  • Requirement in Pregnancy > Lactation → Proteins; Zinc; Folic Acid; Iron
  • Requirement in Lactation > Pregnancy → Vitamin A; Iodine; Vitamin C; Carbohydrates, Calcium
  • Requirement in Pregnancy = Lactation → Vitamin D; Calcium

questions.text: A patient in emergency has the following lab parameters: creatinine 1.5 and BUN 45. The chest x-ray is shown below. In gram staining and culture only, rhinovirus was isolated. The patient is shifted to ICU. What is the treatment of choice in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ceftriaxone plus azithromycin

 

The patient is diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and has been shifted to the ICU. The treatment of choice for ICU-admitted patients with CAP includes a beta-lactam antibiotic like beta-lactam/beta-lactamase inhibitor (BL/BLI) combination like amoxicillin-clavulanic acid or piperacillin-tazobactam, or a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone combined with azithromycin or a respiratory fluoroquinolone such as levofloxacin or moxifloxacin should be administered.

 

Ceftriaxone are used to cover typical bacteria, while azithromycin covers atypical bacteria and provides additional anti-inflammatory properties.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Azithromycin: Insufficient as monotherapy in ICU settings.
 

Option C. Amoxicillin plus clavulanic acid: Lacks coverage for atypical pathogens alone.
 

Option D. Piperacillin Tazobactam plus ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is not a respiratory fluoroquinolone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of a beta-lactam antibiotic and azithromycin is the treatment of choice for ICU-admitted patients with community-acquired pneumonia.

questions.text: Calculate the percentage of burns in a patient that presented to the  emergency with flame burn injury covering the entire  chest and abdomen, the entire right upper limb and full circumference of the  right thigh.(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 36

 

To calculate the percentage of body surface area affected by burns, the Rule of Nines is often used in adults. This method divides the body into sections that represent 9% (or multiples thereof) of the body surface area.

 

As per the case scenario given :

 

  • Chest and abdomen: 18%
  • Right upper limb: 9%
  • Right thigh: 9%

 

Total = 18% (chest and abdomen) + 9% (right upper limb) + 9% (right thigh) = 36%

 

Educational Objective:

 

This calculation as per the case scenario and Wallace rule of 9 results in a total burned body surface area of 36%, which corresponds to option B.

 

Rule of Nine

choices.text: Activated protein C

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady had an uneventful vaginal delivery. On postpartum day 1, she presented with postpartum hemorrhage and complains of visual changes and severe headache. A few hours after the complaint, she is found to be in an unresponsive state and is intubated and put on ventilation. On further examination, she has a BP of 60/40 mmHg and tachycardia, blood sugar is 48 mg/dL. Hematocrit and WBC count was normal. Which of the following drugs would help reverse this state? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Steroids

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation described—postpartum hemorrhage followed by severe headache, visual changes, hypotension, and unresponsiveness—suggests Sheehan syndrome. This condition arises from pituitary apoplexy, which is pituitary infarction secondary to severe blood loss during or after childbirth.

 

  • Sheehan Syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by pituitary gland failure due to substantial blood loss during delivery. The symptoms include persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, lactation failure, headache, visual deficits, and in severe cases, shock, CNS hemorrhage, and even death.
  • Steroids: Hormone replacement with glucocorticoids (steroids) is crucial for managing Sheehan syndrome. Steroids address the adrenal insufficiency and help stabilize the patient’s condition. Initially, glucocorticoids are administered, followed by other hormone replacements as needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inj. Dobutamine: Dobutamine is a beta-agonist used for managing cardiac failure and hypotension. While it may help with blood pressure, it does not address the underlying issue of pituitary failure and would not be the primary treatment for Sheehan syndrome.

 

Option C. Thyroxine: Thyroxine (T4) is a thyroid hormone used in thyroid hormone replacement therapy. While it might be needed later if thyroid function is affected, it does not directly address the acute symptoms of Sheehan syndrome, which is primarily managed with steroids.

 

Option D. Activated Protein C: Activated protein C is used in the management of severe sepsis and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), but it does not treat the pituitary dysfunction associated with Sheehan syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sheehan syndrome is treated primarily with glucocorticoid (steroid) therapy to manage pituitary failure following significant blood loss during or after childbirth.

 

Ref: Page 378, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with a rash after a trip. You observe a vector on his skin. Considering common vector-borne diseases, what is the disease transmitted by the vector shown in the image. ([INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Scrub typhus

 

Explanation:

 

The image provided shows a trombiculid mite, which is commonly involved in the transmission of Scrub Typhus.

 

  • Scrub Typhus is caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi and is primarily transmitted through bites of infected chiggers. The disease is prevalent in the Asia-Pacific region, so exposure in those areas following a rash and the sighting of a trombiculid mite on the skin strongly points to Scrub Typhus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Babesiosis: This is transmitted by Ixodes ticks (deer ticks), affecting red blood cells similar to malaria. It is not related to trombiculid mites.

 

Option B. Anaplasmosis: Transmitted by deer ticks and the western black-legged tick, this disease targets white blood cells. It's also not transmitted by trombiculid mites.

 

Option D. Ehrlichiosis: This disease is transmitted by ticks like the lone star tick and affects white blood cells. It does not involve trombiculid mites.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Scrub Typhus is transmitted by trombiculid mites, specifically the chigger larvae. It is characterized by fever, rash, and a black eschar at the site of the mite bite.

 

DOC – Doxycycline (monotherapy)

 

If severe manifestations – Doxycycline + Azithromycin

questions.text: Identify the virus given in the following replication cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex virus

 

The given image shows the life cycle of the herpes simplex virus (HSV).

 

The herpes virus is a linear double-stranded DNA virus with an icosahedral capsid. The envelope has glycoprotein spikes.

 

Steps of HSV replication:

 

  • The virus enters the cell by fusing with the plasma membrane
  • Viral DNA is released from the capsid at the nuclear pore.
  • Transcription of immediate-early genes - alpha-Proteins
  • Transcription of late genes produces y-proteins which consist of viral structural proteins and participate in virion assembly.
  • Viral DNA is cleaved from concatemers and then packaged into capsids.
  • Viral particles which are enveloped, collect in the endoplasmic reticulum
  • They are transported to cell surface by a vesicular movement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) virus is spherical, enveloped virus with an icosahedral shell and a cone-shaped core which encloses the ribonucleoproteins. It consists of two identical single-stranded, RNA copies, with the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is a characteristic feature of retroviruses.

 

HIV virus life cycle.

 

 

Option C. The hepatitis B virus is a DNA virus. It has an outer envelope and an inner nucleocapsid. It contains two linear strands of DNA in a circular configuration. One of the strands (the plus strand is incomplete resulting in partially double stranded and partially single-stranded DNA.

 

 

Option D. Corona viruses: The genome of coronaviruses is made up of positive sense, unsegmented single-stranded RNA. Coronaviruses are enclosed RNA viruses. They feature surface projections in the form of petals. In the cytoplasm, coronavirus nucleocapsids grow and mature by budding into cytoplasmic vesicles. The structure and life cycle of coronaviruses are depicted in the figures below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes simplex virus (HSV), is characterized by steps involving the fusion of the virus with the plasma membrane, nuclear entry, transcription, replication, capsid assembly, glycosylation, and virus release.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT involved in renal auto-regulation?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Renal sympathetic system fires

 

Renal autoregulation is important to maintain the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Blood flow to kidneys remains normal even when the mean arterial blood pressure very widely between 60 mm Hg and 180 mm Hg. This helps to maintain normal GFR.

The sympathetic nervous system can also influence renal blood flow, but its role is primarily to modulate GFR in response to systemic conditions rather than as part of the intrinsic autoregulatory mechanisms. Therefore, renal sympathetic system firing is not considered a key component of renal autoregulation.

 

Two mechanisms are involved in renal autoregulation:

 

  1. Myogenic response - mechanism that contributes to the maintenance of a relatively constant renal blood flow and GFR
  2. Tubuloglomerular feedback via macula densa. Renin-angiotensin system also plays a role.

 

 

 

 

Macula densa feedback mechanism for autoregulation of glomerular hydrostatic pressure and glomerular filtration rate (GFR) during decreased renal arterial pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubuloglomerular feedback: Incorrect. Tubuloglomerular feedback is a key component of renal autoregulation.

 

Option B. Myogenic reflex: Incorrect. The myogenic reflex is a crucial mechanism in renal autoregulation.The myogenic reflex helps regulate GFR by directly responding to changes in blood pressure (BP) within the afferent arteriole, which supplies blood to the glomerulus. When BP  increases, the afferent arteriole smooth muscle stretches, triggering a contraction (vasoconstriction) that reduces blood flow into the glomerulus, thus decreasing GFR.

 

Option C. Renin-angiotensin system: Incorrect. The renin-angiotensin system supports renal autoregulation, particularly in adjusting the efferent arteriolar resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal autoregulation primarily involves the myogenic response and tubuloglomerular feedback mechanisms to maintain stable GFR. The renal sympathetic system, while involved in renal blood flow regulation, is not part of intrinsic autoregulation mechanisms.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient with critical mitral stenosis presented with atrial fibrillation. He has a history of multiple episodes of transient ischemic attacks. Which of the following are true regarding the prevention of stroke in this patient? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Only aspirin is given
  2. Warfarin is given
  3. Direct oral anticoagulants are not indicated
  4. Mitral valvotomy should be recommended
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

 

For a patient with critical mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation, particularly one with a history of transient ischemic attacks (TIA), anticoagulation therapy is essential.

 

2. Warfarin is the preferred anticoagulant in cases of severe mitral stenosis due to its proven effectiveness in preventing thromboembolic events.

 

3. Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are not recommended in this scenario as they are not indicated for patients with moderate to severe mitral stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Aspirin alone is insufficient to prevent stroke in this context.

 

4. Mitral valvotomy is not recommended at this point because performing the procedure could dislodge existing clots, leading to embolic events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with critical mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation, especially those with a history of TIA, Warfarin should be given for stroke prevention, and direct oral anticoagulants are not indicated.

questions.text: The extracellular concentration of chloride is 100mmol/L and the intracellular concentration is 10 mol/L. What is the equilibrium potential of chloride? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) - 60 mV

 

Nernst equation: EMF (millivolts) = [61/Z] X log [Co / C]

 

  • EMF = electromotive force (Nernst potential)
  • z = charge of ion
  • Co = concentration outside
  • C = concentration inside

 

When using this formula, it is usually assumed that the potential in the extracellular fluid outside the membrane remains at zero potential, and the Nernst potential is the potential inside the membrane.

 

The sign of the potential is negative (-) if a negative ion is diffusing from outside to inside.

Therefore, Nernst potential = 61/-1 * log [100/10] =-61 * log [10] = - 61 mV

 

To get the charge, always check the final charge intracellularly.

 

The potential is negative intracellularly, so the Nernst equation comes out to be -61mV inside the membrane and the closest option is -60 mV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The equilibrium potential for an ion can be calculated using the Nernst equation:

questions.text: All of the following are associated with massive splenomegaly except: (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aplastic anemia

 

All the above are associated with massive splenomegaly except aplastic anemia.

 

Aplastic anemia is characterized by pancytopenia (a reduction in red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets) due to the failure of the bone marrow. A key feature of aplastic anemia is the absence of splenomegaly. In fact, the presence of splenomegaly in a patient with pancytopenia often argues against the diagnosis of aplastic anemia.

 

There are several potential causes of splenomegaly:

 

  1. Liver disease (cirrhosis, hepatitis): Parenchymal liver disease causes increased vascular pressure leading to an increase in spleen size.
  2. Hematologic malignancies (lymphomas, leukemias, myeloproliferative disorders): Neoplastic cells cause infiltration of the spleen leading to splenomegaly.
  3. Venous thrombosis (portal or hepatic vein thrombosis): This leads to an increase in vascular pressure leading to splenomegaly.
  4. Splenic congestion (venous thrombosis, portal hypertension, congestive heart failure).
  5. Cytopenias (Immune thrombocytopenic purpura, autoimmune hemolytic anemia, immune-mediated neutropenia, Felty syndrome): Immune-mediated destruction of red blood cells, white blood cells or platelets lead to functional splenomegaly
  6. Splenic sequestration (pediatric sickle cell disease, hemolytic anemias, thalassemias).
  7. Acute or chronic infection (bacterial endocarditis, infectious mononucleosis, HIV, malaria, tuberculosis, histiocytosis, abscess).
  8. Connective tissue diseases (systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, Adult-onset Still's disease, and some familial autoinflammatory syndromes).[4][5]
  9. Infiltrative disorders (sarcoidosis, amyloidosis, glycogen storage diseases).
  10. Splenic sequestration (pediatric sickle cell, hemolytic anemias, thalassemias).
  11. Focal lesions (hemangiomas, abscess, cysts, metastasis).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aplastic anemia is a syndrome of chronic primary hematopoietic failure. This results in pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia). Splenomegaly is characteristically absent; if it is present, the diagnosis of aplastic anemia should be seriously questioned. Similarly, splenomegaly is also never seen in cases of ITP.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg. 1239, 1173

choices.text: Lateral edge of pectoralis major muscle
Lateral border of latissimus dorsi muscle

questions.text: Which of the following is not a boundary of the triangle of safety for chest tube insertion in a patient with pneumothorax on chest X-ray? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mid-axillary line

 

The mid-axillary line is not a boundary of the triangle of safety. The triangle of safety is defined by specific anatomical landmarks and includes the lateral edge of the pectoralis major muscle, Latissimus dorse, and the fifth intercostal space inferiorly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral edge of pectoralis major muscle: This is the anterior boundary of the triangle of safety.

 

Option C. Base of axilla: This is a boundary of the triangle of safety. It is an important reference point for chest tube insertion to ensure it is performed safely and effectively.

 

Option D. Lateral border of latissimus dorsi muscle: This is a boundary of the triangle of safety. It helps guide the placement of the chest tube in a safe and appropriate location.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triangle of safety for chest tube insertion is a surgical landmark used to guide the safe insertion of chest tubes in patients with pneumothorax. The boundaries of the triangle are the lateral edge of the pectoralis major muscle, the lateral border of the latissimus dorsi muscle, and the 5th intercostal space (ICS) inferiorly, at the level of the nipple above and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle. The base of the triangle is formed by the anterior border of the latissimus dorsi muscle and the lateral edge of the serratus anterior muscle at the base of the axilla.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man was brought to the hospital with complaints of dizziness and breathlessness. During his physical examination, you notice the following discoloration over his face. He is presently being treated with amiodarone, metoprolol, verapamil, lisinopril, and amlodipine. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amiodarone

 

Amiodarone is known to cause skin discoloration, which can appear as a bluish or greyish hue, especially on areas exposed to the sun. This effect is due to the drug's deposition in the skin and can occur after prolonged use. Amiodarone-induced skin discoloration (also known as ceruloderma or blue man syndrome) is the most likely cause of the bluish discoloration in this patient's case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amlodipine: A calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension and angina. Skin discoloration is not a common side effect of amlodipine.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: A beta-blocker used for various heart conditions, including hypertension and arrhythmias. Metoprolol is not typically associated with skin discoloration.

 

Option D. Verapamil: Another calcium channel blocker used for hypertension, angina, and certain arrhythmias. Like amlodipine, it is not commonly associated with causing skin discoloration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiodarone can cause a characteristic bluish or greyish discoloration of the skin, particularly in sun-exposed areas, due to its deposition in the skin after prolonged use. This side effect is not commonly associated with the other medications listed (amlodipine, metoprolol, and verapamil).

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Neonates who are asymptomatic at birth have a lesser risk of later sequelae.
  2. 20-40% are symptomatic at birth.
  3. In developing countries, the rate of transmission of CMV infection to the infant is more common from primary maternal infection than reactivation.
  4. Diagnosis by urine specimen at 4 weeks of age
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3

 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common congenital infection, and understanding the nuances of its transmission, diagnosis, and clinical implications is important.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Congenital CMV Infection:
    • Transmission: Congenital CMV infection can occur from either primary maternal infection (which is when the mother is infected with CMV for the first time during pregnancy) or from reactivation of a prior CMV infection in the mother. The risk of transmission to the fetus is significantly higher in cases of primary maternal infection (around 30%) compared to reactivation (about 1-2%). In developing countries, the prevalence of CMV reactivation is higher, but primary infection remains the more significant source of transmission to the fetus.
    • Asymptomatic vs. Symptomatic: The majority of neonates with congenital CMV are asymptomatic at birth, and these asymptomatic infants have a lower risk of developing long-term sequelae such as sensorineural hearing loss compared to those who are symptomatic at birth.
    • Clinical Presentation: About 10% of neonates with congenital CMV infection are symptomatic at birth. Symptoms can include hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rash, jaundice, chorioretinitis, microcephaly, and thrombocytopenia. These symptoms are associated with a higher risk of long-term complications.
    • Diagnosis: CMV infection can be diagnosed by detecting the virus in urine, saliva, or blood within the first three weeks of life. Diagnosis at four weeks, as mentioned in option 4, is less likely to be reliable because it may represent postnatal infection rather than congenital infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B (1, 2): The percentage of neonates symptomatic at birth is around 10%, not 20-40%.

 

Option C (2, 4): The diagnosis by urine specimen at four weeks is not ideal, and the percentage of symptomatic neonates at birth is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonates who are asymptomatic at birth from congenital CMV infection have a lower risk of long-term sequelae, and transmission is more common from primary maternal infection than from reactivation, especially in developing countries.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles form the pelvic diaphragm?

 

1. Iliococcygeus

2. Pubococcygeus

3. Obturator internus

4. Deep transverse perenei

(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

Iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus are parts of the pelvic diaphragm, which is also known as the levator ani. The pelvic diaphragm is a muscular partition that separates the pelvic cavity above from the perineum below. It consists of two paired muscles, the levator ani and the coccygeus (also known as the ischiococcygeus or the pubococcygeus), and their fascial coverings.

 

The levator ani muscle is a broad, thin muscle that forms the floor of the pelvic cavity. It consists of three parts: the pubococcygeus, the iliococcygeus, and the puborectalis.

 

  • Pubococcygeus muscle is the most medial of the three, and it arises from the pubic bone and the fascia covering the obturator internus muscle.
  • Iliococcygeus muscle arises from the fascia covering the obturator internus muscle and the ischial spine.
  • Puborectalis muscle is a sling-like muscle that forms a loop around the anorectal junction, and it arises from the pubic bone.

 

The coccygeus muscle is a small, triangular muscle that lies posterior to the levator ani muscle. It arises from the ischial spine and the sacrospinous ligament and inserts onto the coccyx.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. The obturator internus forms the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa and is not a part of the levator ani.

 

Option D. The deep transverse perineal muscle is the content of the deep perineal space and contributes to the formation of the perineal body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pelvic diaphragm is formed by the iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles, which are part of the levator ani muscle group. These muscles, including the puborectalis and coccygeus, contribute to the floor of the pelvic cavity and provide structural support, separating the pelvic cavity above from the perineum below.

choices.text: Palpable abdominal lump is the earliest sign
Clinical presentation of gall stones can sometimes be distinguished from gall bladder cancer
Median age of survival is 6 months in all cases

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents to the hospital with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. She was diagnosed with cholecystitis and cholelithiasis and underwent cholecystectomy. The post-operative biopsy reports came back positive for gallbladder carcinoma. What is true about gallbladder carcinoma? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clinical presentation of gall stones can sometimes be distinguished from gall bladder cancer

 

This statement is correct. The clinical presentation of gallstones (cholelithiasis) and gallbladder cancer (carcinoma) can sometimes be distinguished. Gallstones commonly cause symptoms such as biliary colic (episodic, severe right upper quadrant pain) and may lead to acute cholecystitis, which includes symptoms like pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. In contrast, gallbladder carcinoma may present with more persistent or progressive symptoms, including unexplained weight loss and, in some cases, a palpable abdominal mass. The two conditions can have overlapping symptoms, but their clinical courses can be distinguished based on the duration and progression of symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palpable abdominal lump is the earliest sign: This statement is not true. A palpable abdominal lump is not typically the earliest sign of gallbladder carcinoma. Gallbladder carcinoma often presents with nonspecific symptoms such as right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. As the cancer progresses, it may cause other symptoms, but a palpable lump is usually a late finding.

 

Option B. Earliest sign is jaundice: This statement is also not true for most cases of gallbladder carcinoma. Jaundice is more commonly associated with cancers of the bile ducts (cholangiocarcinoma) or pancreatic cancer when the tumor obstructs the bile ducts. While gallbladder carcinoma can cause jaundice if it obstructs the common bile duct, it is not typically the earliest sign of the disease.

 

Option D. Median age of survival is 6 months: This statement is not accurate for all cases of gallbladder carcinoma. The survival rate for gallbladder carcinoma can vary widely depending on factors such as the stage at diagnosis and the extent of surgical resection. While some cases have a poor prognosis with a short median survival, others may have a better outcome if diagnosed at an earlier stage and treated appropriately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Option C is correct because gallstones and gallbladder carcinoma often have distinct clinical presentations, allowing them to be distinguished from each other.

choices.text: Forced expiration against a closed glottis
Forced expiration against an open glottis
Forced inspiration against a closed glottis

questions.text: Which of the following occur during the beginning cough reflex? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Forced expiration against a closed glottis

 

The cough reflex begins with a forced expiration against a closed glottis. The pressure builds up in the lungs and, when the glottis opens, it allows for a rapid expulsion of air to clear the airways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Forced expiration against an open glottis: This does not occur during a cough reflex. While the glottis does eventually open to allow air to be expelled, the characteristic high-pressure expulsion of air is the result of the closed glottis after which it opens.

 

Option C. Forced inspiration against a closed glottis: Inspiration occurs with an open glottis. A closed glottis would prevent air from entering the lungs, so this does not occur during the cough reflex.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because option (a) accurately describes an event that occurs during the cough reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The beginning of the cough reflex involves a forced expiration against a closed glottis, building up pressure in the lungs which is then rapidly released when the glottis opens.Top of Form

questions.text: A person undergoing Anti PD1 immunotherapy (Nivolumab) presents with itching, eczema, and hives-like rashes. Upon histopathological analysis, a blister beneath the outer skin layer is observed. The direct immunofluorescence assessment of the affected areas indicates the presence of Linear C3 and IgG along the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bullous pemphigoid

 

BULLOUS PEMPHIGOID

 

  • Immunobullous disease with a sub epidermal split
  • IgG is the autoantibody deposited
  • Target protein: Hemi desmosomes
  • Target antigens: BPAG 2 > 1
  • No acantholysis
    • Clinical Features: Involves primary lesions (Tense pruritic bullae on Erythematous skin or normal skin) and secondary lesions (Itchy Bullae → Erosions due to scratching).
    • Sites: Trunk, abdomen, flexural aspects of extremities, 10-30% of patients have oral erosions.

 

 

  • Investigation:

 

1. Tzanck smear: Presence of eosinophils and Absence of acantholytic cells.

 

2. Histopathology:

 

 

3. Direct Immunofluorescence: show IgG, C3 linear deposits along Basement Membrane Zone.

 

 

  • Treatment: Topical steroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus Vulgaris: Involves intraepidermal blisters and suprabasal acantholysis (separation of skin cells), which are not described in the provided scenario. Direct Immunofluorescence would typically show intercellular deposits, not linear along the basement membrane.

 

Option C. Dermatitis Herpetiformis: Characterized by intensely itchy blisters and associated with gluten sensitivity. Direct Immunofluorescence shows granular IgA deposits at the tips of dermal papillae, not the linear deposition along the basement membrane.

 

Option D. Pemphigus Foliaceous: Presents with superficial (epidermal) blisters that do not affect the deeper layers of the skin. The immunofluorescence pattern would not show the linear deposition along the basement membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bullous Pemphigoid in patients undergoing immunotherapy is critical due to the potential severity of the condition and the need for prompt and effective management to reduce symptoms and prevent complications. Monitoring for new or worsening symptoms in patients on immunotherapy is essential to catch such reactions early.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in placenta previa? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Warning bleeds

 

Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment, either over or close to the internal cervical os. Key features of placenta previa include:

 

  • Warning bleeds: Also known as sentinel bleeds, are sudden-onset, recurrent, painless vaginal bleeding episodes that typically begin in the third trimester or during labor.
  • Soft, non-tender uterus: The abdominal examination reveals a soft and non-tender uterus, with the fundal height proportionate to the gestational age.
  • Normal fetal heart rate: The fetal heart rate is usually normal unless there is severe bleeding due to a large separation.
  • Malpresentations are common: Due to the lower placement of the placenta.
  • Diagnosis: Confirmed via transabdominal sonography or transvaginal sonography, which is safe and more accurate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dark painful bleeding: This is characteristic of placental abruption, not placenta previa. Placental abruption presents with painful, dark vaginal bleeding due to the premature separation of the placenta.

 

Option C. Uterine tenderness: Uterine tenderness is also a feature of placental abruption, where the uterus becomes firm and tender due to bleeding and clot formation behind the placenta.

 

Option D. Increased large uterine size: This is not a specific feature of placenta previa. Uterine size in placenta previa is proportionate to the gestational age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta previa typically presents with painless, recurrent vaginal bleeding (warning bleeds) in the third trimester or during labor, with a soft, non-tender uterus.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg1940, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 307

questions.text: Match the following developmental milestones: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C

 

The developmental milestones are correctly matched as given in option B -1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c.

 

Transfers objects - 6 to 7 months

 

Social smile - 1 to 2 months

 

Pincer grasp - 9 to 12 months

 

Walks 1-2 steps - 12 to 15 months

 

Educational Objective:

 

Memorize the typical age ranges for key developmental milestones in infants, such as transferring objects, social smiling, pincer grasp, and walking.
